content:
Creating a thread here for the last remaining unknown implication for the finite graph, whether 677 x = y ◇ (x ◇ ((y ◇ x) ◇ y)) implies 255 x = ((x ◇ x) ◇ x) ◇ x.

We know remarkably little about this equation. @Pace Nielsen worked out that the solutions over a generic field to a linear model x⋄y=αx+βyx \diamond y = \alpha x + \beta yx⋄y=αx+βy come in two flavors. Type 1: β\betaβ is negative a primitive 5th root of unity (i.e. a root of x4+x3+x2+x1x^4+x^3+x^2+x^1x4+x3+x2+x1 and α=1−β\alpha = 1-\betaα=1−β (so it is a translation-invariant model). Type 2: β\betaβ is a root of x4+x3+2x2+2x+1x^4+x^3+2x^2+2x+1x4+x3+2x2+2x+1 and α=−β3−β−1\alpha=−\beta^3−\beta−1α=−β3−β−1, which (as observed by @Ben Gunby-Mann) also implies α2+α+1=0\alpha^2+\alpha+1=0α2+α+1=0 (i.e., α\alphaα is a primitive root of unity). Unfortunately, for such models 255 factors as (α2+α+1)(α+β−1)=0.(\alpha^2+\alpha+1)(\alpha+\beta−1)=0.(α2+α+1)(α+β−1)=0.

The smallest non-trivial model is of order 5; this particular example is x⋄y=2x−yx \diamond y = 2x - yx⋄y=2x−y on Z/5Z{\mathbb Z}/5{\mathbb Z}Z/5Z.

Empirically, the magma cohomology approach seems to fail for this equation, but we do not have a satisfactory explanation as to why.
So at least in the Type 1 models we'll have x2=xx^2 = xx2=x. So if I understand correctly that means that the implication is immune to linear models.

I'm searching with Vampire for an order 17 model but it hasn't found one yet.

Ha, no, I was crossing streams in my mind. I was associating the linear models, which even include small ones like the ones I hit, with the enormous ones in the other thread! :upside_down: Neither vampire nor mace4 seems to like finding these guys for me for very much.. thanks for the list!

This 677->255 implication is immune to all linear models based on a (not necessarily commutative) ring where left-invertible ⇔ right-invertible (this includes finite rings and finite matrices over a field for instance).

The required equations to obey 677 are β(α+βαβ)=1\beta(\alpha+\beta\alpha\beta)=1β(α+βαβ)=1 and 0=α+β3+β2α20=\alpha+\beta^3+\beta^2\alpha^20=α+β3+β2α2. We want to show the condition for 255, which is (1+α+α2)(β+α−1)=0(1+\alpha+\alpha^2)(\beta+\alpha-1)=0(1+α+α2)(β+α−1)=0. To proceed, we work with β\betaβ and γ=α+β−1\gamma=\alpha+\beta-1γ=α+β−1. Note that the first assumption makes β\betaβ invertible. The two assumptions are

γβ+β−1γ=β2−β+1−β−1−β−2,γ2=(β−2−β−1−β−2)γ.\gamma\beta + \beta^{-1}\gamma = \beta^2 - \beta + 1 - \beta^{-1} - \beta^{-2} , \qquad \gamma^2 = (\beta-2-\beta^{-1}-\beta^{-2})\gamma .γβ+β−1γ=β2−β+1−β−1−β−2,γ2=(β−2−β−1−β−2)γ.

The first equation tells us how β\betaβ commutes through γ\gammaγ: intuitively it is mapped as β→−β−1\beta\to-\beta^{-1}β→−β−1. This is an involution, so we can get useful mileage from commuting through γ2\gamma^2γ2. Namely, we write β−1γ2β−γ2=[β−1γ,γβ+β−1γ]\beta^{-1}\gamma^2\beta-\gamma^2 = [\beta^{-1}\gamma, \gamma\beta+\beta^{-1}\gamma]β−1γ2β−γ2=[β−1γ,γβ+β−1γ] and compute the LHS using the formula for γ2\gamma^2γ2 and the RHS using the formula for γβ+β−1γ\gamma\beta+\beta^{-1}\gammaγβ+β−1γ. After reordering β,γ\beta,\gammaβ,γ using the first identity, we get a formula of the form f(β)γ=g(β)f(\beta)\gamma=g(\beta)f(β)γ=g(β). Right-multiplying by γ\gammaγ and reducing γ2\gamma^2γ2 we get h(β)γ=0h(\beta)\gamma=0h(β)γ=0. If I didn't mess up my calculations, we have enough to deduce (3−3β+β2+3γ−βγ−γβ+γ2)γ=0(3-3\beta+\beta^2+3\gamma-\beta\gamma-\gamma\beta+\gamma^2)\gamma=0(3−3β+β2+3γ−βγ−γβ+γ2)γ=0, which is 255.

I think I have also used Magma to rule out all non-commutative linear models modelled on a vector space with scalar field of characteristic 0 or positive characteristic less than 10000. In this online calculator one can run 

for p in PrimesUpTo(10000) do
    F<a, b, c> := FreeAlgebra(FiniteField(p),3);
    B := [(-1)+(b*a)+(b*b*a*b),(a)+(b*b*a*a)+(b*b*b),(b*b*a*c)+(b*b*c)+(b*c)+(c)];
    I := ideal<F | B>;
    if not ((-1)+(a*a*a)+(a*a*b)+(a*b)+(b) in I and (a*a*c)+(a*c)+(c) in I) then
        print(p);
    end if;
end for;
print("Done");

to test small characteristics. (And testing the rationals is similar).

Sorry I didn't make this clearer on the previous thread. When I worked out the two solutions over a generic field, I actually worked out the full reduction system over (potentially noncommutative) rings. For a map of the form x⋄y=ax+by+cx\diamond y=ax+by+cx⋄y=ax+by+c, a reduction system is given by

ba↦ab,b3↦a2b+b2+a2−a,a2b↦−a3−ab−b+1,ba\mapsto ab,\qquad b^3\mapsto a^2b+b^2+a^2-a,\qquad a^2b\mapsto -a^3-ab-b+1,ba↦ab,b3↦a2b+b2+a2−a,a2b↦−a3−ab−b+1,

a4↦ab2+2a3+ab−a2+b+a−2,b2ac↦−b2c−bc−c,a^4\mapsto ab^2+2a^3+ab-a^2+b+a-2,\qquad b^2ac\mapsto -b^2c-bc-c,a4↦ab2+2a3+ab−a2+b+a−2,b2ac↦−b2c−bc−c,

a2c↦−ac−c,b2c↦abc+aca^2c\mapsto -ac-c,\qquad b^2c\mapsto abc+aca2c↦−ac−c,b2c↦abc+ac

(255 does indeed follow for such linear maps over rings.)
Did you do that by hand or do you have software which can do that automatically? I'd like to compute the graph for linear implications.
I can't believe it took 70 days into the project before we finally were able to make use of Magma...
And it still isn't very useful (I was able to rediscover something close to your 1117 -> 2441 example with it though).

(with this code in case you are curious. The ideal is the needed equations to be a linear model of 1117, the final two inclusions come from 2441)

F<a, b, c> := FreeAlgebra(Rationals(),3);
B := [(-1)+(b*a*b*a),(a)+(b*a*a),(b*a*b*b)+(b*b),(b*a*b*c)+(b*a*c)+(b*c)+(c)];
I := ideal<F | B>;
GroebnerBasis(I);

(-1)+(a*a)+(a*b*a*a)+(a*b*a*b)+(a*b*b)+(b) in I;
(a*b*a*c)+(a*b*c)+(a*c)+(c) in I;

I used code I wrote (and have updated over the years) in Mathematica. I'm happy to share it if you are interested---just shoot me an email.
That's some useful stuff, I really could not find a standard package to do it for me and was dreading writing it myself.
(deleted)
So do we really not have a single model that is known not to be linear?

A diagnosis of linear models is that all (finite) linear models are Latin squares (the condition b(a+bab)=1b(a+bab)=1b(a+bab)=1 makes bbb invertible, then the condition (1+b2a)a=−b3(1+b^2a)a=-b^3(1+b2a)a=−b3 makes aaa invertible). It's clear that 677 implies that left multiplication is invertible, since im(Ly)\text{im}(L_y)im(Ly​) is the whole magma and surjective implies injective. Both prover9 and mace4 are inconclusive on whether right multiplication has to be invertible in a general 677 magma (I am not very good with these tools though). This could influence the type of counterexamples we seek.

Terry used x⋄y=yx\diamond y=yx⋄y=y as a fall-back rule for his gigantic 1518 example because this was an easy way to fulfill the equation for most of the table. Here one option is to use a linear fallback, but the linear models are somewhat complicated. Another option is to use as a fallback a magma satisfying equation 14 (x=y⋄(x⋄y)x = y \diamond (x \diamond y)x=y⋄(x⋄y)), but modifying the squares (or the products involving squares). Then for most x,yx,yx,y the equation would reduce to x=y⋄x2x=y\diamond x^2x=y⋄x2. I didn't push this yet, in part because I wasn't sure if I had to make the magma right-cancellative.

Hmm, the latter option looks problematic because it's going to be hard to have x=y⋄x2x = y \diamond x^2x=y⋄x2 and x=y⋄(x⋄y)x = y \diamond (x \diamond y)x=y⋄(x⋄y) both hold for most x,yx,yx,y (if one replaces yyy by S2yS^2 yS2y then the first equation suggests that S2y⋄(x⋄S2y)S^2 y \diamond (x \diamond S^2 y)S2y⋄(x⋄S2y) should equal yyy, not xxx). One could perhaps ask an ATP whether the constant-squaring case x⋄x=0x \diamond x = 0x⋄x=0 is at all permissible, if so that might be a possible model to pursue.

Sorry, you're right, imposing equations 14 and 13 at the same time makes no sense. I had started an attempt by partitioning the magma in two subsets, but I don't have anything concrete at this stage.

The question of right-cancellation remains. In some sense, we need multiplication to preserve all the information in the right operand (due to left-cancellation) and at least "half" of the information in the left operand: indeed, the equation can be written as x=Lx′(Lx′′(y))x = L_{x'}(L_{x''}(y))x=Lx′​(Lx′′​(y)) where x′=y⋄xx' = y\diamond xx′=y⋄x and x′′=y⋄x′x''=y\diamond x'x′′=y⋄x′, and we want the pair of Lx′L_{x'}Lx′​ and Lx′′L_{x''}Lx′′​ to uniquely determine xxx (for a given yyy). So maybe a better starting point would be to try a carrier M=P×PM=P\times PM=P×P and (x1,x2)⋄(y1,y2)=f(x2,y1,y2)(x_1,x_2)\diamond(y_1,y_2) = f(x_2,y_1,y_2)(x1​,x2​)⋄(y1​,y2​)=f(x2​,y1​,y2​) to find an example of 677 magma that is not right-cancellative. Then hopefully it helps with making a 255 counterexample.

Bruno Le Floch ha dicho:

Both prover9 and mace4 are inconclusive on whether right multiplication has to be invertible in a general 677 magma (I am not very good with these tools though).

If we impose bijectivity of left and right multiplications, then 677 implies 255. Here is a Prover9 proof (it only uses left injectivity and right surjectivity):
PROVER9 677 plus left and right mult bijective implies 255 PROOF.txt

Terence Tao ha dicho:

One could perhaps ask an ATP whether the constant-squaring case x⋄x=0

677 plus left multiplication bijective plus x^2 = y^2 implies 255.

I'm running a search of 677+left mult bijective + equation against 255, where equation ranges in [2,4694]. For now there are only 225 candidates left; I'll update soon.

The specific idea of dropping uniformly the "same half" of the left operand fails. In the equation written (in the finite case) as x = (y ◇ x) ◇ ((y ◇ (y ◇ x)) ◇ y), that would mean that the only dependence on y1 is from the last variable, and this dependence never disappears because this y is acted on by bijective L_{y ◇ x} and L_{y ◇ (y ◇ x)}. So we need more mixing.

So, that was a complete failure: mutation didn't work at all here, despite a fresh run.

I had one last faint hope that I simply had too few samples, but even after I had the dozens of linear models to play with thanks to Ibrahim, no luck. They're too tightly coupled together to use as good seeds. If you remove too few cells you wind up completing back to the original, and if you don't, you get an enormous number of linked failures which don't seem repairable. Reducing to a partial solution using fewer elements and trying to grow that, which helped before, also didn't work. Frankly, both vampire and mace4 have trouble finding the known solutions for me without a lot of prompting at larger N, although that might not apply to less coupled solutions, to be fair.

Efforts to use 614 as a base and then migrate back towards 677 didn't work either, and I can't even use the trick of driving toward a solution gradually by imposing some of an equation's implications because 677 doesn't have any in our set.

For evolutionary approaches to work, you need at least to be able to jump from one useful state (target or not) to another efficiently. This fails when useful states are too rare or it takes too long to get a new state, both of which seem to be true here.

Jose Brox said:

Bruno Le Floch ha dicho:

Both prover9 and mace4 are inconclusive on whether right multiplication has to be invertible in a general 677 magma (I am not very good with these tools though).

If we impose bijectivity of left and right multiplications, then 677 implies 255. Here is a Prover9 proof (it only uses left injectivity and right surjectivity):
PROVER9 677 plus left and right mult bijective implies 255 PROOF.txt

This feels like an important clue to me. For finite magmas we get left injectivity for free. If we can get a human proof of why right surjectivity implies 255 that should make it clearer what a counterexample might look like (or what a proof might look like - this implication could well be true for finite magmas!).

One possible thought is to try to adapt a technique that worked for weak central groupoids (see blueprint), which is to find a small (e.g., order 2) "relaxed" solution to 677 (where the magma operation is slightly multivalued), and try to build an extension of that by some pseudo-greedy algorithm. This amounts to imposing a coloring on the magma and imposing some rules about how the color of x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y relates to the color of xxx and yyy (e.g., if xxx is red and yyy is blue, then x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y must be blue, but if xxx and yyy are both red, then x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y could be either red or blue, etc.). It may be possible to "decouple" the magma structure this way, for instance one could try to make the equation 13 hold for red elements and 14 hold for blue elements, thus dodging the issue that 13 and 14 are not compatible with each other. However I don't know if there is a practical relaxed magma that can be used as a base (of course one can always use the trivial relaxation in which every color output is permitted, but this doesn't gain anything).

Terence Tao ha dicho:

f we can get a human proof of why right surjectivity implies 255 that should make it clearer what a counterexample might look like

Ok! I will have a look at it later and translate it from "telegraphic superposition calculus" to something more human-readable.

Jose Brox ha dicho:

I'm running a search of 677+left mult bijective + equation against 255, where equation ranges in [2,4694]. For now there are only 225 candidates left; I'll update soon.

24 candidates have survived a 10min Prover9 search. So, together with 677 (and left multiplication bijective) it is probably also safely to assume any of
[411, 513, 623, 642, 817, 1020, 1035, 1048, 1223, 1238, 1251, 1426, 3659, 4065, 4073, 4131, 4276, 4293, 4321, 4343, 4380, 4591, 4599, 4695]
against 255.

Later I will look at combinations of these additional equations.
There are no 677 models of size 2, 3, 4, and 6. I've been running a Vampire search for a model of order 8 for 26 hours but it still hasn't found one.

It's relatively rare for a two-variable equation such as 677 to have so few models, and so much restriction on the order. Weak central groupoids (1485) also had a lot of restrictions on the order, but that's a three-variable equation, so less surprising (it imposes n3n^3n3 constraints rather than n2n^2n2 constraints).

On the other hand, in contrast to say 854, 677 does not seem to be implying a lot of other laws (Equation Explorer only lists the trivial consequence 614, even if one assumes finiteness). So this equation is imposing some "rigidity", but the rigidity is coming from an unknown source.

The key point of the prover9 proof seems to be that 677 says that x=y⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y),x = y \diamond (x \diamond ((y \diamond x) \diamond y),x=y⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y), so Rx−1(x)⋄x=x=Rx−1(x)⋄(x⋄(x⋄Rx−1(x)))R_x^{-1}(x) \diamond x = x = R_x^{-1}(x) \diamond (x \diamond (x \diamond R_x^{-1}(x)))Rx−1​(x)⋄x=x=Rx−1​(x)⋄(x⋄(x⋄Rx−1​(x))) and thus x=x⋄(x⋄Rx−1(x))x = x \diamond (x \diamond R_x^{-1}(x))x=x⋄(x⋄Rx−1​(x)) by left injectivity.

From here, the point is that 677 + left injectivity tell us y=(x⋄y)⋄((x⋄(x⋄y))⋄x)y = (x\diamond y) \diamond ((x \diamond (x \diamond y)) \diamond x)y=(x⋄y)⋄((x⋄(x⋄y))⋄x), so x⋄Rx−1(x)=x⋄((x⋄x)⋄x)x \diamond R_x^{-1}(x) = x \diamond ((x \diamond x) \diamond x)x⋄Rx−1​(x)=x⋄((x⋄x)⋄x), and so Rx−1(x)=(x⋄x)⋄x.R_x^{-1}(x) = (x \diamond x) \diamond x.Rx−1​(x)=(x⋄x)⋄x. Right multiplying this by xxx gives 255.

To rephrase the argument: if we have y⋄x=xy \diamond x = xy⋄x=x, then by 677 x=y⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=y⋄(x⋄(x⋄y))x = y \diamond (x \diamond ((y \diamond x) \diamond y)) = y \diamond (x \diamond (x \diamond y))x=y⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=y⋄(x⋄(x⋄y)), hence by left-cancellativity x=x⋄(x⋄y)x = x \diamond (x \diamond y)x=x⋄(x⋄y). Meanwhile from 677 with yyy replaced by xxx we also have x=x⋄(x⋄(Sx⋄x))x = x \diamond (x \diamond (Sx \diamond x))x=x⋄(x⋄(Sx⋄x)), so by left-cancellativity again y=Sx⋄xy = Sx \diamond xy=Sx⋄x and hence (Sx⋄x)⋄x=x(Sx \diamond x) \diamond x = x(Sx⋄x)⋄x=x which is 255 for xxx.

So we don't even need full right surjectivity; just being able to solve y⋄x=xy \diamond x = xy⋄x=x for each xxx would give 255. Conversely, 255 clearly implies that y⋄x=xy \diamond x = xy⋄x=x is solvable, so this is an equivalent form of 255.

This now reminds me of the ruleset of the (automatically generated) greedy algorithm refuting 677->255 for infinite magmas (which is conveniently accessible from the 677 Equation Explorer page). The 677 ruleset (ignoring Rule 0, which says that ⋄\diamond⋄ is a partial function) is

  1. If y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z, z⋄y=wz \diamond y = wz⋄y=w, x⋄w=ux \diamond w = ux⋄w=u, then x=y⋄wx = y \diamond wx=y⋄w (this is just 677)
  2. If x⋄y=y⋄x=xx \diamond y = y \diamond x = xx⋄y=y⋄x=x then x⋄x=yx \diamond x = yx⋄x=y
  3. If x⋄x=yx \diamond x = yx⋄x=y, x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z, and z⋄x=xz \diamond x = xz⋄x=x then z=xz = xz=x
  4. If x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z, y⋄w=xy \diamond w = xy⋄w=x, and z⋄y=wz \diamond y = wz⋄y=w, then z⋄w=yz \diamond w = yz⋄w=y.

Rule 2 can be strengthened with the above analysis: if y⋄x=xy \diamond x = xy⋄x=x then x=x⋄(x⋄y)x = x \diamond (x \diamond y)x=x⋄(x⋄y) so if we also have x⋄y=xx \diamond y=xx⋄y=x then xxx is idempotent, and by left-cancellativity we have x=yx=yx=y. Not sure yet where Rule 3 and Rule 4 are coming from though.

A proof of Rule 3 (for finite magmas at least): by hypothesis, z=Sx⋄xz = Sx \diamond xz=Sx⋄x. From 677 we have Sx=x⋄(Sx⋄((Sx⋄x)⋄x))=x⋄(Sx⋄x)=x⋄zSx = x \diamond (Sx \diamond ((Sx \diamond x) \diamond x)) = x \diamond (Sx \diamond x) = x \diamond zSx=x⋄(Sx⋄((Sx⋄x)⋄x))=x⋄(Sx⋄x)=x⋄z hence by left-cancellability x=zx = zx=z as required.

Rule 4 holds since w=y⋄(w⋄((y⋄w)⋄y))=y⋄(w⋄z)w = y \diamond (w \diamond ((y \diamond w) \diamond y)) = y \diamond (w \diamond z)w=y⋄(w⋄((y⋄w)⋄y))=y⋄(w⋄z), so y=z⋄(y⋄((z⋄y)⋄z))=z⋄w.y = z \diamond (y \diamond ((z \diamond y) \diamond z)) = z \diamond w. y=z⋄(y⋄((z⋄y)⋄z))=z⋄w.

Given that one needs to avoid solving the equation y⋄x=xy \diamond x = xy⋄x=x to obtain a counterexample, a possible relaxed base magma to choose is the carrier {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1} with 0⋄1=1⋄1=00 \diamond 1 = 1 \diamond 1 = 00⋄1=1⋄1=0 and 1⋄0,1⋄11 \diamond 0, 1 \diamond 11⋄0,1⋄1 permitted to be either 000 or 111, thus y⋄xy \diamond xy⋄x cannot equal xxx when x=1x=1x=1. An extension of this relaxed base would thus be a magma colored in two colors, 0 and 1, such that the product of anything with a 1-colored object must be 0-colored. As far as I can tell, this is compatible with 677 (but perhaps having an ATP confirm this would be great). So if we can create such a 2-colored finite 677 magma with at least one element 1-colored, we have refuted 677 -> 255 for finite magmas!

One natural place to start is to see if it is possible to start with some base 677 magma, such as a linear model, declare it to be 0-colored, and see if one can add a single 1-colored element to it and preserve 677. Given how rigid the 677 magmas seem to be, this seems unlikely, but perhaps discovering the obstruction to this working would be instructive.
OK, adjoining 1-colored objects to an existing 0-colored magma would not work, as it would violate left-surjectivity (the product of a 0-colored object with anything would not be 1-colored).

Matthew Bolan ha dicho:

I think the "for all" quantifiers have the wrong scope in the third assumption, they should be inside the parentheses.

Thank you, this is indeed the case! This one is subtle: according to its manual, when parsing free variables in clauses and formulas Prover9 assumes they are universally quantified at the outermost level. I had understood this fact to be relative, i.e., to mean "at the outermost level of each subformula given by parentheses", but it is in fact absolute, meaning "at the outermost level of the global formula". Hence
x*y = x*z -> y = z works as intended, but
(x*y = x*z -> y = z)<->(all u all v exists w (w*u = v)) actually means
all x all y all z ((y*x = z*x -> y = z) <-> (all u all v exists w (w*u = v))) instead of
(all x all y all z (y*x = z*x -> y = z)) <-> (all u all v exists w (w*u = v)). The variant
all x all y all z (y*x = z*x -> y = z) <-> all u all v exists w (w*u = v) also works as intended.

@Jose Brox :

meaning "at the outermost level of the global formula"

In first-order model theory, writing down the simplest possible definition of the satisfaction relation naturally leads to interpreting "free variables as universally quantified", in the sense that a formula P(x,y,… )P(x,y,\dots)P(x,y,…) with free variables counts as satisfied in a model precisely if its universal closure ∀x.∀y.… .P(x,y,… )\forall x. \forall y. \dots . P(x,y,\dots)∀x.∀y.….P(x,y,…) is satisfied in that model.

The treatment of free variables in Prover9/Mace4 attempts to follow the same convention. This explains why the manual's explanation is so unnuanced. The authors failed to anticipate that the users would not necessarily be logicians familiar with this convention.

I think we actually already have an example of some kind of "ramification" for the linear models. Bruno's degree 307 counterexample in the HN law project is very interesting, over Z[a,b]\mathbb Z[a,b]Z[a,b] the polynomial 307b+307307b + 307307b+307 is in the relevant ideal, and if 307307307 is invertible, then b=−1b=-1b=−1 and no linear counterexample can exist, but modulo 307 we have a linear counterexample.
the degree 103 example has a similar property, though I think it also has counterexamples in characteristic 5.
There are examples of similar phenomena in the main project by the way, for example law 895 (Which is a law for abelian groups of exponent 2) only has linear models in characteristic 2.

I have a vague intuition that such exceptional primes may be the best bet for finding counterexamples from the cohomological approach, because often the relevant matrices in the linear algebra calculations are going to have full rank (after quotienting out the coboundaries) and so in general characteristic will not have an interesting kernel that we can use to produce non-trivial extensions. But if there is ramification then we can hope to sneak in an interesting counterexample at specific primes. Except that for this particular equation, we only get magmas at relatively large primes like 5, 7, or 11, so the probability of getting ramification is sadly somewhat low. Though your examples at 307 and 103 do indicate that maybe all hope is not lost...

There's something very "mixing" about 677. It doesn't have easy models like left-absorptive or right-absorptive models that one can hope to modify, nor does it involve the squaring map which seems to simplify the structure (in that a law involving three magma operations and a square seems easier to satisfy than four magma operations and no square). Also it can't be easily expressed purely in terms of left multiplication or purely in terms of right multiplication, but instead mixes together both. So, other than using a linear ansatz, there don't seem to be cheap ways to try to make it more likely to create a 677 magma. Also the fact that half of the linear models are idempotent is also weakening the power of the cohomological method to construct interesting magmas.

The cohomological approach cannot yield counterexamples to 255. The set of (right-)cancellative 677 models is stable under cohomological extensions (see proof below), so for each xxx we have a solution y=Rx−1(x)y=R_x^{-1}(x)y=Rx−1​(x) of y⋄x=xy\diamond x=xy⋄x=x, which we know implies 255. Copying Terry Tao's version of the argument here: y⋄x=x=677y⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=y⋄(x⋄(x⋄y))y\diamond x=x\overset{677}{=}y\diamond(x\diamond((y\diamond x)\diamond y))=y\diamond(x\diamond(x\diamond y))y⋄x=x=677y⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=y⋄(x⋄(x⋄y)) so by left-cancellativity x⋄(x⋄y)=x=677x⋄(x⋄(Sx⋄x))x\diamond(x\diamond y)=x\overset{677}{=}x\diamond(x\diamond(Sx\diamond x))x⋄(x⋄y)=x=677x⋄(x⋄(Sx⋄x)) so by left-cancellativity y=Sx⋄xy=Sx\diamond xy=Sx⋄x hence (Sx⋄x)⋄x=x(Sx\diamond x)\diamond x=x(Sx⋄x)⋄x=x, equation 255.

Why is right-cancellativity stable? Consider (x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,as+bt+c+f(x,y))(x,s)\diamond(y,t)=(x\diamond y,as+bt+c+f(x,y))(x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,as+bt+c+f(x,y)) with s∗t=as+bt+cs*t=as+bt+cs∗t=as+bt+c a linear model. We know (finite) linear models are right-cancellative (in other words aaa is invertible). If (x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x′,s′)⋄(y,t)(x,s)\diamond(y,t)=(x',s')\diamond(y,t)(x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x′,s′)⋄(y,t) then x⋄y=x′⋄yx\diamond y=x'\diamond yx⋄y=x′⋄y and as′+bt+c+f(x′,y)=as+bt+c+f(x,y)as'+bt+c+f(x',y)=as+bt+c+f(x,y)as′+bt+c+f(x′,y)=as+bt+c+f(x,y). The first equation gives x=x′x=x'x=x′ by right-cancellativity of the base. The second equation then gives s′=ss'=ss′=s by invertibility of aaa.

That said, the cohomological approach could still possibly provide nonlinear examples of 677, which may be of independent interest.

Here is a naive exploration idea that doesn't really see the commutativity: we fix a finite group G (represented by its multiplication table and inverse function). We can try to construct a SAT problem with O(∣G∣2)O(|G|^2)O(∣G∣2) variables and O(∣G∣3)O(|G|^3)O(∣G∣3) clauses: basically, for each subterm of the equation that we consider, we have a |G|^2 many variables corresponding to the graph of the subterm (so for each subterm sss and g,h∈Gg, h \in Gg,h∈G, we have a variable sg,hs_{g,h}sg,h​ corresponding to s(g)=hs(g) = hs(g)=h. For each multiplication in the equation, we have |G|^3 3-term clauses that correspond to s1(g)=h1∧s2(g)=h2⇒s1s2(g)=h1h2 s_1(g) = h_1 \wedge s_2(g) = h_2 \Rightarrow s_1 s_2(g) = h_1 h_2s1​(g)=h1​∧s2​(g)=h2​⇒s1​s2​(g)=h1​h2​. Similar, for function application we have |G|^3 3-term clauses corresponding to s(g)=h1∧f(h1)=h2→(f∘s)(g)=h2 s(g) = h_1 \wedge f(h_1) = h_2 \rightarrow (f \circ s)(g) = h_2 s(g)=h1​∧f(h1​)=h2​→(f∘s)(g)=h2​ (for inversion we only need |G|^2 2-term clauses). The equation itself gives us also 2|G|^2 clauses. Then we add that each subterm should be a function and fff should be a derangement, and then we ask a SAT solver whether this has a solution.

fof(rtcanctosurj, axiom, (! [U, V, W] : mul(V, U) = mul(W, U) => V = W) => (! [Y, Z] : ? [X] : mul(X, Y) = Z)).

I think here there is the same mistake that I made with Prover9: in TPTP language, quantification has higher precedence than binary connectives, so you need to move the parentheses to the inside of the formula.
fof(rtcanctosurj, axiom, ! [U, V, W] : (mul(V, U) = mul(W, U) => V = W) => ! [Y, Z] : ? [X] : (mul(X, Y) = Z)).

@Bruno Le Floch Thanks for explaining why the implication is immune to the cohomological method! Disappointing of course - this looked like our best shot to finishing off the last implication - but at least we now have a satisfactory explanation for why the numerical implementation of the cohomological method was not working.

So now we need a new method. Bernard is already proposing the translation invariant model, which seems to be the best option we currently have. Regarding other constructions, I only have some largely negative results to report here.

  1. One variant of the cohomological construction is a piecewise linear model (x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,αx,ys+βx,yt)(x,s) \diamond (y,t) = (x \diamond y, \alpha_{x,y} s + \beta_{x,y} t)(x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,αx,y​s+βx,y​t). Let's say the base is the order 5 model, then we have 50 unknowns here αx,y,βx,y\alpha_{x,y}, \beta_{x,y}αx,y​,βx,y​. For idempotent xxx, αx,x,βx,x\alpha_{x,x}, \beta_{x,x}αx,x​,βx,x​ have to be coefficients of a linear model (and in particular will exhibit right cancellativity) but a priori there is no such requirement for off-diagonal coefficients αx,y,βx,y\alpha_{x,y}, \beta_{x,y}αx,y​,βx,y​. On the other hand, 677 will force 50 separate quartic equations on these 50 unknowns, which is quite unappealing (with a translation invariant ansatz one can cut this down to 10 equations in 10 unknowns, which is still bad) but also would suggest there are only finitely many solutions in any given field, with no particular reason for any one of the αx,y\alpha_{x,y}αx,y​ to vanish. So the chance of getting a non-right-cancellative example here is slim. [EDIT: one can combine this model with the cohomological model to consider the more complex operation (x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,αx,ys+βx,yt+f(x,y))(x,s) \diamond (y,t) = (x \diamond y, \alpha_{x,y} s + \beta_{x,y} t + f(x,y))(x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,αx,y​s+βx,y​t+f(x,y)), but this doesn't add any capabilities - if we had such a model that was not right-cancellative, then we could set f=0f=0f=0 and already get a model that was not right-cancellative.]

  2. Another option is the extension method: start with an existing model, e.g., a linear model MMM, and add a few elements to it with the hope of making a new model. One cannot just add one element: if one adds a new element 000 to an existing 677 magma MMM, then by left-invertibility we must have x⋄0=0x \diamond 0 = 0x⋄0=0 for all x∈Mx \in Mx∈M, which is not actually possible since by previous analysis for each xxx the only possible solution to y⋄x=xy \diamond x = xy⋄x=x is y=Sx⋄xy = Sx \diamond xy=Sx⋄x. So the first available option is to add two elements 0,10,10,1 to MMM and impose the laws x⋄0=1x \diamond 0 = 1x⋄0=1, x⋄1=0x \diamond 1 = 0x⋄1=0 for x≠1,0x \neq 1,0x=1,0. If one can also assure that 0⋄0,1⋄0≠00 \diamond 0, 1 \diamond 0 \neq 00⋄0,1⋄0=0, say, then one is done, as now there is no solution to x⋄0=0x \diamond 0 = 0x⋄0=0. So perhaps one could explore if an ATP thinks this is a viable approach?

On the other hand, 677 gives x=0⋄(x⋄((0⋄x)⋄0))x = 0 \diamond (x \diamond ((0 \diamond x) \diamond 0))x=0⋄(x⋄((0⋄x)⋄0)) which simplifies using the given hypotheses to x=0⋄0x = 0 \diamond 0x=0⋄0, contradiction.

Recording another failed approach as a negative result. If one defines f(x,y):=(y⋄x)⋄yf(x,y) := (y \diamond x) \diamond yf(x,y):=(y⋄x)⋄y, then 677 can be written as x=y⋄(x⋄f(x,y))x = y \diamond (x \diamond f(x,y))x=y⋄(x⋄f(x,y)). So, using left cancellativity, one can describe the relation between ⋄\diamond⋄ and fff by two axioms:

  1. If y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z, then z⋄y=f(x,y)z \diamond y = f(x,y)z⋄y=f(x,y).
  2. If y⋄z=xy \diamond z = xy⋄z=x, then x⋄f(x,y)=zx \diamond f(x,y) = zx⋄f(x,y)=z.

So I tried first choosing the function f:M×M→Mf: M \times M \to Mf:M×M→M, and seeing if one could build a magma operation ⋄\diamond⋄ that obeyed Axiom 1 and Axiom 2 for that choice of fff. The point is that the axioms are rather simple: both axioms assert that one entry in the multiplication table propagates to another. The problem is that these axioms don't commute, and in principle after N applications of these axioms, a single entry y⋄x=zy \diamond x = zy⋄x=z on the table can propagate into 2^N other entries, leading almost certainly to collisions. One somehow wants to choose an fff with a special property that the propagation rules of Axiom 1 and Axiom 2 (i.e., the functions (y,x,z)↦(z,y,f(x,y))(y,x,z) \mapsto (z,y,f(x,y))(y,x,z)↦(z,y,f(x,y)) and (y,z,x)↦(x,f(x,y),z)(y,z,x) \mapsto (x,f(x,y),z)(y,z,x)↦(x,f(x,y),z)) obey a lot of algebraic relations that cuts down on this complexity, but setting fff to be too simple (e.g., constant) quickly leads one to violate the requirement that each entry of the multiplication table has a unique answer. Of course, because we have linear models, we know that it is possible to satisfy both of these axioms with a linear choice of fff; I tried a little bit with the scenario in which fff stays linear but we allow for nonlinear ⋄\diamond⋄, but didn't make much headway there. (Also, if fff is right-cancellative then ⋄\diamond⋄ will be also, since we already have left-invertibility, so even if I did make a non-linear model out of this, it still wouldn't refute 255.)

I think the correct statement you get from taking linear combinations of the polynomials is that the only nontrivial commutative linear models are Type 1 models in characteristic 5 (which must be of the form 2x-y, as you said).

To be explicit about this, 513 implies that for commutative linear models a(b3+b2+b+1)=0a(b^3+b^2+b+1)=0a(b3+b2+b+1)=0 and b4=1b^4=1b4=1, so as long as we're in an integral domain, either we have the model y∗x=xy*x=xy∗x=x (which doesn't satisfy 677) or b3+b2+b+1=0b^3+b^2+b+1=0b3+b2+b+1=0. In case 2, b is both a root of x3+x2+x+1x^3+x^2+x+1x3+x2+x+1 and x4+x3+2x2+2x+1x^4+x^3+2x^2+2x+1x4+x3+2x2+2x+1, and since (x2+1)(x3+x2+x+1)−x(x4+x3+2x2+2x+1)=1(x^2+1)(x^3+x^2+x+1)-x(x^4+x^3+2x^2+2x+1)=1(x2+1)(x3+x2+x+1)−x(x4+x3+2x2+2x+1)=1 the model must be trivial. However, in case 1 we have x3+x2+x+1=0x^3+x^2+x+1=0x3+x2+x+1=0 and x4−x3+x2−x+1=0x^4-x^3+x^2-x+1=0x4−x3+x2−x+1=0, which has solutions only over characteristic 5 (similarly, (2x3−4x2+x+2)(x3+x2+x+1)−(2x2−3)(x4−x3+x2−x+1)=5(2x^3-4x^2+x+2)(x^3+x^2+x+1)-(2x^2-3)(x^4-x^3+x^2-x+1)=5(2x3−4x2+x+2)(x3+x2+x+1)−(2x2−3)(x4−x3+x2−x+1)=5). In characteristic 5, x4−x3+x2−x+1=(x+1)4x^4-x^3+x^2-x+1=(x+1)^4x4−x3+x2−x+1=(x+1)4, so again if we are in an integral domain the only root is x=−1x=-1x=−1, and we are left with the solution x⋄y=2x−yx\diamond y=2x-yx⋄y=2x−y, as mentioned. Reporting some "fieldwork":
1) The only other equations (up to 4694) that can be added to 677+513 without provably implying 255 are:

  • 411 x = x * (x * (x * (x * x))), which is just 513 with y=xy=xy=x.
  • 4380 (x * x) * x = x * (x * x), which is implied by 677+513 (put y=xy=xy=x and cancel on the left twice).
  • 3659 x * x = (x * x) * (x * x), which doesn't seem to be implied by 677+513 (plus left bijectivity and yx=xyx=xyx=x not always solvable), survives 30min in Prover9.

I have checked 677+513+3659 (plus left bijectivity) against 255 with Prover9, Vampire, and Vampire in CASC mode, for 30min each without getting a proof, so it seems a safe combination to take.

2) We also know that a model of 677+513 against 255 must have size at least 14 [UPDATED].

3) Other idea I have tried: I have looked at models of 513 against 255, and it turns out that they allow "complete failure" of right injectivity, i.e., there are models satisfying xy=zyxy = zyxy=zy. As we already know this doesn't work with 677, and neither does it if all rows of the multiplication table are equal but one; but if it is all rows but two,
all x all y all z ((x!=0 & x!=1 & z!=0) -> x*y = z*y),
then the problem 677+513+3659+most rows equal (with left bijectivity) survives 30min in Prover9 (I'm looking for models of size 13 now).

(Deleted, silly comment)

4) On the other hand, 577+4599 against 255 (plus the extra clauses) progresses faster: any model must have size at least 17. This is somewhat suspicious, as problems that exhaust sizes quick tend to don't actually have models (i.e., the implication can be proven in those cases), but the progress is not that fast. In any case, I have tried to prove the implication without success for 30min with Vampire and Vampire-CASC (but Vampire in normal mode exits quickly, only saying "killed" :melting_face: ), and for 3h in Prover9 (still running, just in case).

I managed to convert the greedy construction of a 677 magma into a Kisielewicz type model (which I believe to in fact be a free 677 magma (or at least contain such a free magma as a submagma), though I have not proved this). Unfortunately, it is infinite and I see no way to convert it to a finite model, but I report it here in case it somehow is helpful.

The carrier MMM is the positive integers {1,2,3,… }\{1,2,3,\dots\}{1,2,3,…}. We will build the multiplication table recursively, one row at a time: thus to define x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y for a given yyy we assume that x′⋄y′x' \diamond y'x′⋄y′ has already been defined for all y′<yy' < yy′<y. The multiplication rule is then

Rule. If x<y=2z3(x⋄z)⋄xx < y = 2^z 3^{(x\diamond z) \diamond x}x<y=2z3(x⋄z)⋄x for some z∈Mz \in Mz∈M, then x⋄y=zx \diamond y = zx⋄y=z. Otherwise, x⋄y=2x3yx \diamond y = 2^x 3^yx⋄y=2x3y.

Note that there is only one possible choice of zzz that can be assigned to x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y in the former case (namely, the number of times 222 divides yyy). Also, by construction in that case zzz and xxx are both less than yyy, so to evaluate the rule one only needs to compute products x′⋄y′x' \diamond y'x′⋄y′ with y′<yy' < yy′<y. So the rule is recursively well defined. Intuitively, for "most" x,yx,yx,y, x⋄y=2x3yx \diamond y = 2^x 3^yx⋄y=2x3y will be larger than x,yx,yx,y and "remember" all the information about xxx and yyy (this is a capability that only seems possible in infinite models), but for some exceptional x,yx,yx,y, x⋄yx \diamond yx⋄y will be smaller than yyy, and return the number of times 222 divides yyy instead. Because of this, y⋄(x⋄w)y \diamond (x \diamond w)y⋄(x⋄w) can become xxx for certain x,y,wx,y,wx,y,w (and specifically www of the form (y⋄x)⋄y(y \diamond x) \diamond y(y⋄x)⋄y, which is where 677 will come from.

From definition we have the following property:

Lemma 1: For any x,y∈Mx, y \in Mx,y∈M, we either have x,y<x⋄y=2x3yx, y < x \diamond y = 2^x 3^yx,y<x⋄y=2x3y, or x,x⋄y<y=2z3(x⋄z)⋄xx, x \diamond y < y = 2^z 3^{(x \diamond z) \diamond x}x,x⋄y<y=2z3(x⋄z)⋄x with z:=x⋄yz := x \diamond yz:=x⋄y. In particular, in both cases we have x<max⁡(y,x⋄y)x < \max( y, x \diamond y )x<max(y,x⋄y).

From this and a somewhat involved case analysis we have

Lemma 2: For any x,y∈Mx, y \in Mx,y∈M, we have x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=2x3(y⋄x)⋄yx \diamond ((y \diamond x) \diamond y)) = 2^x 3^{(y \diamond x) \diamond y}x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=2x3(y⋄x)⋄y.

Proof: Write z:=y⋄x z := y \diamond xz:=y⋄x, w:=z⋄yw := z \diamond yw:=z⋄y, and u:=x⋄wu := x \diamond wu:=x⋄w, then we wish to show u=2x3wu = 2^x 3^wu=2x3w. Suppose for contradiction this were not the case, then by Lemma 1 we have x<w=2u3(x⋄u)⋄xx < w = 2^u 3^{(x \diamond u) \diamond x}x<w=2u3(x⋄u)⋄x. From Lemma 1 again we have y<max⁡(x,y⋄x)=max⁡(x,z)≤max⁡(x,w)y < \max(x, y \diamond x) = \max(x,z) \leq \max(x,w )y<max(x,y⋄x)=max(x,z)≤max(x,w) and z<max⁡(y,z⋄y)=max⁡(y,w)z < \max(y, z \diamond y) = \max( y, w )z<max(y,z⋄y)=max(y,w), hence y<wy < wy<w. Since w=z⋄yw=z \diamond yw=z⋄y, we conclude from Lemma 1 that w=2z3yw = 2^z 3^yw=2z3y; comparing with our previous formula for www, we conclude u=zu=zu=z and y=(x⋄z)⋄xy = (x \diamond z) \diamond xy=(x⋄z)⋄x. From Lemma 1 we have x<max⁡(z,x⋄z)x < \max(z,x \diamond z)x<max(z,x⋄z), x⋄z<max⁡(x,(x⋄z)⋄x)=max⁡(x,y)x \diamond z < \max(x,(x \diamond z) \diamond x)=\max(x,y)x⋄z<max(x,(x⋄z)⋄x)=max(x,y), and y<max⁡(x,y⋄x)=max⁡(x,z)y < \max(x,y \diamond x)=\max(x,z)y<max(x,y⋄x)=max(x,z). Thus only zzz can be the largest of x,y,z,x⋄zx, y, z, x \diamond zx,y,z,x⋄z, so y<y⋄x=zy < y \diamond x = zy<y⋄x=z and hence z=2y3xz = 2^y 3^xz=2y3x by Lemma 1. Since x⋄z<z=2y3xx \diamond z < z = 2^y 3^xx⋄z<z=2y3x we then have x⋄z=yx \diamond z = yx⋄z=y by Lemma 1, hence y=(x⋄z)⋄x=y⋄xy = (x \diamond z) \diamond x = y \diamond xy=(x⋄z)⋄x=y⋄x, contradicting Lemma 1. □\Box□

Remark: the ability to prove this lemma roughly corresponds to the ability to close the greedy argument when constructing 677 magmas, where in both cases the point is that no "unexpected collisions" show up to derail things.

Now we can verify 677:

Lemma 3: For any x,yx,yx,y we have y⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=xy \diamond (x \diamond ((y \diamond x) \diamond y)) = xy⋄(x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y))=x.

Proof: By Lemma 2 and the multiplication rule, it suffices to show that y<2x3(y⋄x)⋄yy < 2^x 3^{(y \diamond x) \diamond y}y<2x3(y⋄x)⋄y. From Lemma 1 we have y<max⁡(x,y⋄x)y<\max(x,y \diamond x)y<max(x,y⋄x) and max⁡(y⋄x)<max⁡(y,(y⋄x)⋄y)\max(y \diamond x) < \max(y, (y \diamond x) \diamond y)max(y⋄x)<max(y,(y⋄x)⋄y), hence y<max⁡(x,(y⋄x)⋄y))<2x3(y⋄x)⋄yy < \max(x, (y \diamond x) \diamond y)) < 2^x 3^{(y \diamond x) \diamond y}y<max(x,(y⋄x)⋄y))<2x3(y⋄x)⋄y, as required. □\Box□

From Lemma 1 we have x⋄y≠yx \diamond y \neq yx⋄y=y for all yyy, so in particular 255 fails in this model.

I continued the search for translation-invariant 677 models of the form x⋄y=xf(x−1y)x \diamond y = x f(x^{-1} y)x⋄y=xf(x−1y), as suggested by @Bernhard Reinke, across all groups of order up to 17. Aside from the previously identified cases, namely Z5\mathbb{Z}_5Z5​ and Z11\mathbb{Z}_{11}Z11​, only Z24\Z_2 ^4Z24​ supports such models. In addition, for all such models, fff has a fixed point (so 255 holds).

In this example, the permutation fff is a product of three 5-cycles:
fff = (0)(1 4 2 14 9)(3 10 11 15 13)(5 6 12 7 8).
The elements of Z24\Z_2 ^4Z24​ are indexed in such a way that the group operation is the bit-wise sum mod 2. In particular, the five elements in each cycle have sum 0. All of this strongly suggests that we are in fact looking at a linear model over F16\mathbb{F}_{16}F16​, with fff acting as multiplication by a 5-th root of unity, though I have not checked it.

Interestingly, the time taken by Gurobi to prove non-existence of models differs significantly across the remaining groups of order 16: 7 groups are "hard" (~1 hour), 5 are "easy" (< 2 minutes), and 1 is "intermediate" (~10 minutes).

Given the size of counterexamples lately it's hard to put too much weight on the resistance this one's putting up, but am I the only one wondering if this one's actually true?

Are there properties of finite magmas we haven't invoked yet, or consequences of them that ATPs would have trouble detecting?

Okay, I have some questions at this point.
The possibility that 677 has very few models in general seems like a major obstacle to me, especially when trying search based approaches. If 677 has only, say, 6 models of order ≤13\leq 13≤13, then the fact that our searches fail to find models of certain combinations if equations really doesn't tell us much.

I wish I could confirm my hunches myself, but the thread has grown too long to search efficiently given my current time constraints, and I suspect that many of you have tacit knowledge not written up here, so I think I'll ask a series of questions instead. Hopefully, the answers will help refine the main axis of effort instead of just satisfying my personal curiosity.

  1. Do we know any finite models of 677 that are not outright cancellative? If not, do we have proof (or at least some heuristic) telling us not to expect such models? NB if we cannot expect such models, then imposing 4599 and similar equations whose models tend to be very noncancellative is perhaps not that promising.
  2. Do we know any finite models of 677 that have even order? If not, do we have reason not to expect such models?
  3. Do we know two non-isomorphic finite models of 677 that have the same order? If not...
  4. How many different models do we know? How many models of order less than 15?

For question 2, there are linear models of even order, for example over F16F_{16}F16​. The answer to question 3 is yes, for example there are two non-isomorphic linear models of order 7. For question 4, AFAIK we only know linear models and cohomological extensions of linear models, and I think there are only linear models known below order 15. I'd have to check which linear models are isomorphic in order to give an exact count.

Douglas McNeil said:

Are there properties of finite magmas we haven't invoked yet, or consequences of them that ATPs would have trouble detecting?

Technically, proofs that some implication always holds in a finite magma can be arbitrarily difficult (which doesn't mean that we should expect this particular problem to be difficult; indeed, I don't think this one's true). One could look up famous such proofs (starting with Artin-Zorn perhaps?) to see what sorts of properties they invoke, and whether we're missing any of them.

Summary of what we know.

  • All known finite models are linear or cohomological extensions thereof, typically nonlinear.
  • List of linear models on Z/pZ for primes p up to 500. More general (e.g., non-commutative) linear models are mostly understood.
  • 677 implies left-cancellative. Finite linear 677 implies right-cancellative too. Cohomological extensions keep cancellativity. 677 and cancellativity implies 255.
  • Assuming 677, equation 255 is equivalent to ∀x ∃y y*x=x. Piecewise affine extensions (x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,αx,ys+βx,yt+f(x,y))(x,s)\diamond(y,t)=(x\diamond y,\alpha_{x,y}s+\beta_{x,y}t+f(x,y))(x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,αx,y​s+βx,y​t+f(x,y)) by a field preserve that property so cannot produce counterexamples.
  • 677 is incompatible with 0!=1∧∀y,y*1=0 —also incompatible with 0!=1∧∀y,(y=1 or y*1=0) by a quick prover9 run I just did and also with ∀x(x=0 or x=1 or (x*0=1 and x*1=0)).
  • 677 together with any of {411,513,623,...} does not imply 255. —particular interest for 513 combined with translation-invariance (no new model for n≤16) or with 3659.
  • Some hope to use translation-invariant models.
  • Some inconclusive usage of rule sets and a concrete Kisielewicz type infinite counterexample.
  • An idea of using a relaxed base magma..

Some other equations with very few finite models seem to have a good reason for that. The cardinal of finite central groupoids must be a square because the square of the adjacency matrix is an all-1 matrix. For weak central groupoids we have a conjecture that the cardinal is a square or twice a square. Is there anything special about the cardinal of 677 models, or the size of cosets, etc?

A curious ramification. Linear models x⋄y=ax+by+cx\diamond y=ax+by+cx⋄y=ax+by+c over Z/pZ (p prime) are nicely classified between type 1 with a=1−ba=1-ba=1−b and bbb a primitive 10th root of unity and c=0c=0c=0, and type 2 with b4+b3+2b2+2b+1=0b^4+b^3+2b^2+2b+1=0b4+b3+2b2+2b+1=0 and a=−b3−b−1a=-b^3-b-1a=−b3−b−1 and a2+a+1=0a^2+a+1=0a2+a+1=0 and arbitrary ccc. The parameter ccc can be set to zero by shifting magma elements x→x+(a+b−1)−1cx\to x+(a+b-1)^{-1}cx→x+(a+b−1)−1c in all models except one which is both of type 1 and 2, namely x⋄y=5x−4y+cmod  31x\diamond y=5x-4y+c\mod 31x⋄y=5x−4y+cmod31. This number comes from gcd⁡(b4−b3+b2−b+1, b4+b3+2b2+2b+1)=31\gcd(b^4-b^3+b^2-b+1, \ b^4+b^3+2b^2+2b+1)=31gcd(b4−b3+b2−b+1, b4+b3+2b2+2b+1)=31. That might be a hint to this case being slightly more flexible than usual linear models. In particular it is a non-idempotent translation-invariant model. That said, it is big, so I'm not sure it is an improvement over the 7-element magmas as a base.

Pick some (y,t)(y,t)(y,t). By 255 on the base we have some xxx with x⋄y=yx\diamond y=yx⋄y=y, so x⋄(y⋄((x⋄y)⋄x))=x⋄yx\diamond(y\diamond((x\diamond y)\diamond x))=x\diamond yx⋄(y⋄((x⋄y)⋄x))=x⋄y hence y⋄((x⋄y)⋄x)=yy\diamond((x\diamond y)\diamond x)=yy⋄((x⋄y)⋄x)=y as we already observed. t=s⋄x,y(t⋄…((s⋄x,yt)⋄…s))t = s\diamond_{x,y} \bigl(t\diamond_{\dots}((s\diamond_{x,y} t)\diamond_{\dots} s)\bigr)t=s⋄x,y​(t⋄…​((s⋄x,y​t)⋄…​s))

where dots denote unimportant indices. Crucially, the same left-multiplication map s⋄x,y(… )=αx,ys+…s\diamond_{x,y} (\dots) = \alpha_{x,y}s + \dotss⋄x,y​(…)=αx,y​s+… appears twice. If αx,y∈End(M)\alpha_{x,y}\in\mathrm{End}(M)αx,y​∈End(M) is not injective, then two different sss (say, s1,s2s_1,s_2s1​,s2​) will have equal left-multiplications, but then we can cancel all these by left cancellativity so eventually s1=s2s_1=s_2s1​=s2​. For the more general extension models (x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,s⋄x,yt)(x,s) \diamond (y,t) = (x \diamond y, s \diamond_{x,y} t)(x,s)⋄(y,t)=(x⋄y,s⋄x,y​t), what this shows is that whenever x⋄y=yx \diamond y = yx⋄y=y, the left multiplication maps Lsx,y:t↦s⋄x,ytL^{x,y}_s: t \mapsto s \diamond_{x,y} tLsx,y​:t↦s⋄x,y​t have to depend injectively on sss: Lsx,y=Ls′x,y  ⟺  s=s′L^{x,y}_s = L^{x,y}_{s'} \iff s =s'Lsx,y​=Ls′x,y​⟺s=s′. In piecewise affine models, these left multiplication maps are translations (composed with a fixed invertible map), so injectivity and finiteness forces all translations to be attained, and then we can solve s⋄x,yt=ts \diamond_{x,y} t = ts⋄x,y​t=t. So if we want to keep an extension model, these left multiplication maps have to be genuinely more complicated than translations, but then it's much less likely that the required equations are going to hold.

Another way of thinking about it: one feature of linear models ⋄x,y\diamond_{x,y}⋄x,y​ is that if Lsx,y,Ls′x,yL^{x,y}_s, L^{x,y}_{s'}Lsx,y​,Ls′x,y​ agree at one location, they in fact agree at all locations: s⋄x,yt=s′⋄x,yt  ⟹  s⋄x,yt′=s′⋄x,yt′s \diamond_{x,y} t = s' \diamond_{x,y} t \implies s \diamond_{x,y} t' = s' \diamond_{x,y} t's⋄x,y​t=s′⋄x,y​t⟹s⋄x,y​t′=s′⋄x,y​t′. [Geometrically: two lines of the same slope are either parallel or identical.] So injectivity of s↦Lsx,ys \mapsto L^{x,y}_ss↦Lsx,y​ implies injectivity of s↦Lsx,yts \mapsto L^{x,y}_s ts↦Lsx,y​t for any fixed ttt, i.e., the Rtx,yR^{x,y}_tRtx,y​ are injective, hence invertible by finiteness, and we get 255. So we need operations ⋄x,y\diamond_{x,y}⋄x,y​ for which left-multiplication by different elements s,s′s,s's,s′ can agree in some locations but not in others.

Forgetting about extensions for the moment, maybe this suggests semilinear models such as x⋄y=αx+βxyx \diamond y = \alpha_x + \beta_x yx⋄y=αx​+βx​y that are linear in the second variable but not the first. Ugh, but this particular model just leads to a total mess when one computes 677.

There's something very special about linear (or affine) binary operations - the composition of linear operations is again linear, and this is essential in keeping the number of equations and the number of unknowns matching when considering an equation like 677. If one starts looking at quadratic maps, for instance, suddenly one gets way more equations than unknowns when one matches coefficients. If there was some other class of binary operations x,y↦x⋄yx, y \mapsto x \diamond yx,y↦x⋄y than linear or affine for which operations such as x,y↦(y⋄x)⋄yx,y \mapsto (y \diamond x) \diamond yx,y↦(y⋄x)⋄y had the "same" complexity as the original map (in that they are described by exactly the same number of parameters), then we might have a shot, but I can't think of any other candidates... [EDIT: Okay, translation invariant models are one other candidate of this type. And I guess, trivially, the entire class of arbitrary binary operations are also of this type.]

Reporting a very silly thing I tried, just to take it off the table: instead of trying to extend or enlarge a base magma, I tried for an embarrassingly long amount of time to experiment with the reverse operations of quotienting a magma by an equivalence relation, or restricting to a submagma. For instance I was poking around to see if the linear magma model had any quotients that were not linear. But then I realized that any law such as 255 would be automatically preserved by passing to quotients or submagmas, so there is probably no point in trying to use such constructions (unless perhaps as a base magma for some construction for which we don't currently have an immunity result). [EDIT: there is perhaps a possibility that one could start with a magma that doesn't obey either 677 or 255, then perform a quotienting to enable 677 but not 255, which might work if we had some useful way of constructing a magma that "nearly" obeys 677, but I have no proposal in this direction.]

That's a good point. It's possible that if we understand the infinite model better then we could figure out how to place a cofinite equivalence relation on it that one can quotient by to create a useful finite 677 model. Though this hasn't been super successful in group theory - we completely understand what the free group on a fixed set of generators looks like, but this doesn't exactly make it easy to generate finite groups.

In group theory we have this extremely useful family of groups coming from permutations on an arbitrary set, with Cayley's theorem guaranteeing that all the other groups are basically subgroups of this model. (Similarly for monoids and functions on an arbitrary set.) There's also the group of general linear transformations of vector spaces, leading to the extremely rich and useful field of representation theory. I guess there's no reason to expect a similarly useful family for 677 though. For some other laws, we had the left-absorptive or right-absorptive models which were also useful (though more as base models to modify than models to take submagmas of), but again these are not available here. Instead we just have a twp strange families of linear models,some extensions of them, and a handful of infinite models...

Not much positive progress on my previous approach, but I at least have a model problem to propose:

  • Can one build a finite left-cancellative magma that obeys 677 at least 99% of the time (thus, the 677 equation holds for at least 99% of pairs x,yx,yx,y) but for which right surjectivity only holds 1% of the time (i.e., the equation x⋄a=bx \diamond a = bx⋄a=b is solvable for at most 1% of pairs a,ba,ba,b)?

(The reason why I ask for failure of right surjectivity rather than failure of 255 is that it is easy to make the one-variable equation 255 fail 100% of the time just by modifying the multiplication table on the diagonal, so I need a two-variable condition instead.)

The hope is that if such a counterexample can be found, then one can modify the example on a small portion fo the multiplication table to exactly solve 677 but fail to solve 255. (This may be related to a discussion @Zoltan A. Kocsis (Z.A.K.) and I had back in October on magmas that nearly obey a given law.)

Anyway, to construct such a counterexample, it suffices to find a left-cancellative operation ⋄\diamond⋄ on a finite carrier MMM that does two things:

  1. The expression f(x,y):=(y⋄x)⋄yf(x,y) := (y \diamond x) \diamond yf(x,y):=(y⋄x)⋄y "forgets" information about yyy, in the sense that at most 1% of pairs in M×MM \times MM×M can be of the form (x,f(x,y))(x, f(x,y))(x,f(x,y)).
  2. The expression Ly−1xL_y^{-1} xLy−1​x forgets the same information about yyy, that is to say for a given x,y,y′x,y,y'x,y,y′, one has f(x,y)=f(x,y′)f(x,y) = f(x,y')f(x,y)=f(x,y′) if and only if Ly−1x=Ly′−1xL_{y}^{-1} x = L_{y'}^{-1} xLy−1​x=Ly′−1​x. (One could maybe tolerate a a failure of this if-and-only-if 1% of the time for the purposes of this model problem.)

Then if one modifies the operation on the small number of pairs (x,f(x,y))(x,f(x,y))(x,f(x,y)) so that x⋄f(x,y)=Ly−1xx \diamond f(x,y) = L_y^{-1} xx⋄f(x,y)=Ly−1​x (maybe doing a few more modifications to preserve left cancellativity), one obtains 677 basically 99% (or maybe 98%) of the time while (probably) violating right surjectivity quite a bit (because of all the collisions Ly−1x=Ly′−1xL_{y}^{-1} x = L_{y'}^{-1} xLy−1​x=Ly′−1​x.

Here is an amusing reformulation of 677. Given a left-cancellative magma (M,⋄)(M,\diamond)(M,⋄), define a good sequence to be a sequence (xn)n∈Z(x_n)_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}(xn​)n∈Z​ obeying the recursion xn+1⋄xn=xn+2x_{n+1} \diamond x_n = x_{n+2}xn+1​⋄xn​=xn+2​. By left-cancellativity, every pair (x0,x1)∈M×M(x_0, x_1) \in M \times M(x0​,x1​)∈M×M extends uniquely to a good sequence, which looks like
…,Lx0−1x1,∣x0,x1,x1⋄x0,(x1⋄x0)⋄x1,… \dots, L_{x_0}^{-1} x_1, | x_0, x_1, x_1 \diamond x_0, (x_1 \diamond x_0) \diamond x_1, \dots…,Lx0​−1​x1​,∣x0​,x1​,x1​⋄x0​,(x1​⋄x0​)⋄x1​,…
(with the bar being notation for indicating the element of this sequence indexed by zero). We call this the good sequence generated by x0,x1x_0,x_1x0​,x1​.

Let GGG be the set of good sequences. Given any integers j,kj,kj,k, let Aj,k:G→GA_{j,k}: G \to GAj,k​:G→G be the function that takes a good sequence (xn)n∈Z(x_n)_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}(xn​)n∈Z​ to the good sequence generated by xj,xkx_j, x_kxj​,xk​. Thus for instance Aj,j+1A_{j,j+1}Aj,j+1​ is just the shifted sequence
…,xj−1,∣xj,xj+1,… \dots, x_{j-1}, |x_j, x_{j+1}, \dots …,xj−1​,∣xj​,xj+1​,…
and is an invertible transformation on GGG. The maps Aj+1,jA_{j+1,j}Aj+1,j​ can also be seen to be invertible.
However, the other Aj,kA_{j,k}Aj,k​ can be non-invertible. (For instance, the invertibility of A1,−1A_{1,-1}A1,−1​ is equivalent to right cancellability.)

so A3,0A1,0gA_{3,0} A_{1,0} gA3,0​A1,0​g is the sequence
…,∣(y⋄x)⋄y,x,x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y),… \dots, |(y \diamond x) \diamond y, x, x \diamond ((y \diamond x) \diamond y), \dots…,∣(y⋄x)⋄y,x,x⋄((y⋄x)⋄y),…
and hence A1,2A3,0A1,0gA_{1,2} A_{3,0} A_{1,0} gA1,2​A3,0​A1,0​g is the sequence

Specifying a left-cancellative operation is equivalent to specifying a class of good sequences that is shift-invariant, and such that any pair x0,x1x_0,x_1x0​,x1​ uniquely generates a good sequence. I like your model problem, but so far did not have any success. On the other hand I think your reformulation in terms of Aj,kA_{j,k}Aj,k​ complicates things.

Central groupoids, which are subject to a three-variable equation (hence expected to be more restrictive), can often be modified by a "switching" operation that acts very simply on the graph. In an n-element magma it affects sqrt(n) entries in the multiplication table if I remember correctly. So it wouldn't be crazy to hope that for our two-variable equation 677 we could also modify a large linear magma "by hand" in a reasonable number of places to get a new magma that violates 255. I don't think we've explored this enough. The problem is that 677 is very mixing somehow.

Maybe we could learn something about sizes of cosets, and the flow of information, from having a model that is not right-cancellative. However, the only current hope to produce them is piecewise affine models which involve solving huge systems of nonlinear equations.

I don't think we've ruled out models of the form x⋄y=axy+cxx\diamond y = a_x y + c_xx⋄y=ax​y+cx​ that are linear in one of the two arguments only. We could even try something like x⋄y=aπ(x)y+cxx\diamond y = a_{\pi(x)} y + c_xx⋄y=aπ(x)​y+cx​ with π ⁣:M→{0,1}\pi\colon M\to\{0,1\}π:M→{0,1} or a similar tiny set.

I think at this stage it's worth considering the possibility that the implication might hold in the finite case (e.g. something like right-cancellativity holds over all finite models).

Perhaps the tools of classical universal algebra could help in such investigations? I mean things like subdirect representation, congruence lattices, characterizations of direct irreducibility.

Here's a concrete idea: If finite directly irreducible 677-magmas satisfy 255, then of course all finite 677-magmas do. Over certain algebraic structures, one can determine direct reducibility by counting solutions to equations. For example, a finite Heyting algebra is directly reducible precisely if the equation x∨¬x=⊤x \vee \neg x = \topx∨¬x=⊤ has more than 2 solutions (btw this is why all finite Boolean algebras have 2n2^n2n elements).

I wonder if 677-magmas admit any similar solution-counting characterization for direct reducibility. If so, these could be added as assumptions to Prover9 to see if they allow us to conclude e.g. right-cancellativity or 255.

Throughout, assume translation-invariance in an exponent 2 group (which is thus commutative, so we write the operation additivitely). Also throughout, assume 677+injectivity of fff.

Write p:=f(0)p:=f(0)p:=f(0) and q:=f(p)q:=f(p)q:=f(p). Equation 677 at h=0h=0h=0 yields

f2(p+q)=0.f^2(p+q)=0.f2(p+q)=0.

Next, equation 677 at h=ph=ph=p yields

p=f(p+f(p+q+f(q))).p=f(p+f(p+q+f(q))).p=f(p+f(p+q+f(q))).

I'm beginning to understand now that the task of establishing 677 on 1−ε1-\varepsilon1−ε of pairs x,yx,yx,y (or 1−ε1-\varepsilon1−ε of shifts hhh, in the translation-invariant model) is rather different than that of establishing 677 everywhere. The problem with the latter is that it is exactly determined: ∣M∣2|M|^2∣M∣2 equations on ∣M∣2|M|^2∣M∣2 unknowns, or ∣M∣|M|∣M∣ equations on ∣M∣|M|∣M∣ unknowns in the translation-invariant case. But once one allows a failure rate, one now has an underdetermined problem, basically (1−ε)∣M∣(1-\varepsilon) |M|(1−ε)∣M∣ equations on ∣M∣|M|∣M∣ unknowns in the translation-invariant case, so it is much easier to build examples. On the other hand, obstructions such as the exponent 2 construction only require a small number of equations and unknowns and so are invisible to the 1−ε1-\varepsilon1−ε variant of the problem.

For three-variable equations such as the associative law, there can be ways to relate a specific operation on the multiplication table with quite "generic" entries of the multiplication table, with the upshot being that if such a table obeys the law 99% of the time then it is possible to modify it on a small number of entries to be obeyed 100% of the time. A classic example of this is the Blum-Luby-Rubinfeld linearity testing result: if a function f:F2n→F2nf: F_2^n \to F_2^nf:F2n​→F2n​ obeys the linearity property f(x)+f(y)=f(x+y)f(x) + f(y) = f(x+y)f(x)+f(y)=f(x+y) 99% of the time, then one can modify fff a ilttle bit to be perfectly linear. The point, roughly speaking, is that one can work out what fff should be at xxx by looking at f(x+y)−f(y)f(x+y)-f(y)f(x+y)−f(y) for a "typical" yyy and use this to perform "error correction". Here it is essential that the functional equation has at least two variables, in contrast to the one-variable situation we have with translation-invariant 677. This is also related to the fact that three-variable equational laws are highly overdetermined, in contrast to two-variable laws that are perfectly determined.

In the construction I gave with carrier M=F×F3M = F \times F^3M=F×F3, each of the vertical slices {x}×F3\{x\} \times F^3{x}×F3 are self-contained submagmas which are completely arbitrary. It could be that an improved version of the construction leads to a method where one can place an arbitrary 677 structure on each such slice and then fill in the multiplication table for off-diagonal products (x,s)⋄(y,t)(x,s) \diamond (y,t)(x,s)⋄(y,t) with x≠yx \neq yx=y so that there is significant failure of right cancellativity "off the diagonal", but this wouldn't affect 255 which can be verified entirely within a single slice at a time. (This is related to the previous observation that we can assume without loss of generality that the magma is generated by a single element, so there is no point playing with models in which the magma splits into disjoint submagmas.)

Anyway, I think I'm already to abandon my tentative "99% construction" method here, as the hoped for "rigidity", "stability", or "error-correcting" phenomenon (in which a 99%-perfect 677 magma could be corrected into a 100%-perfect 677 magma) looks unlikely to be the case. (A model situation is when 677 fails for a single pair x,yx,yx,y. As far as I know we have no way of ruling out this scenario, but also there is no obvious way to "repair" such a near-miss magma to obey 677 without exception.)

In my experience, similar "reconstruction" tends to be quite difficult in the absence of rigid structure. For example, if you start with the axioms x*x=0, x*(y*z)=(x*y)*z, x*0=0*x = x, then you get only Z/2Zn\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}^nZ/2Zn as your finite models.

But if you allow for these axioms to hold only up to epsilon, you immediately get many models where you have to change a fixed proportion of the operation table on {0,..,2n}\{0,..,2^n\}{0,..,2n} before you get a group, much less Z/2Zn\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}^nZ/2Zn. IIRC the operation given below, defined on a large {0,..,n=2k}\{0,..,n=2^k\}{0,..,n=2k}, constitutes such an example:

0 * y = y
x * 0 = x
x * x = 0
x * y = min{x,y}   if x,y both in {1..n} and x /= y

If you do have some rigid structure, e.g. cancellativity/injectivity, such examples do not arise (like in the theorem of Gowers and Long), but cancellativity/injectivity is precisely what we do not want in this case.

The rationale for the last two is the following: over noncommutative rings the linear models cannot work. But we can keep removing axioms from the base ring until perhaps the two varieties (for 677 and 255) start differing. Even if we don't ask for distributivity or opposite elements for addition, the mere presence of 000 and 111 produces the same sets of polynomials (when written as sums of monomials) as the ring case, but this doesn't necessarily mean that their solutions are still the same. I have checked with Vampire that if we ask for annihilation (0∗x=0=x∗00*x = 0 = x*00∗x=0=x∗0) and left distributivity, then (with 677 anti 255) there must be opposite elements even if there is no right distributivity; and Mace4 is interestingly faster without any distributivity law, so I'm conduncting two experiments: one with annihilation, one without, both without distributivity nor opposite elements.

Apologies for being stubbornly fixated with a problem that is probably unproductive for the project, but I'm captivated by its beauty :big_smile: My "toothbrushing" sketch proof wasn't directed to find the bound for each row of fff (fixed xxx), but for the sum of the rows (that I believe is what you were asking with your condition 1 upstream). The combinatorial problem would be as follows, denoting [n]:={1,…,n}[n]:=\{1,\ldots,n\}[n]:={1,…,n}:

Let f,g:[n]×[n]→[n]f,g:[n]\times [n]\to[n]f,g:[n]×[n]→[n] be two functions with g(⋅,y)g(\cdot,y)g(⋅,y) bijective for all (fixed) yyy and such that
1) f(x,y)=f(x,z)f(x,y) = f(x,z)f(x,y)=f(x,z) iff g(x,y)=g(x,z)g(x,y) = g(x,z)g(x,y)=g(x,z).
2) f(x,y)=f(x,z)f(x,y) = f(x,z)f(x,y)=f(x,z) implies f(g(x,y),y)≠f(g(x,y),z)f(g(x,y),y)\neq f(g(x,y),z)f(g(x,y),y)=f(g(x,y),z).
For each xxx, let mxm_xmx​ denote the cardinal of the range of f(x,⋅)f(x,\cdot)f(x,⋅). Then
∑x∈[n]mx≥F(n),\sum_{x\in [n]} m_x \geq F(n),∑x∈[n]​mx​≥F(n),
where F(n)F(n)F(n) is to be determined and sharp.

My idea wasn't having into account some kind of collisions, but there is some subtlety in the iterative process: Let RxR_xRx​ denote the xxx-th row of the table of f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y), and write ∼x\sim_x∼x​ for the equivalence relation in [n][n][n] given by y∼xzy \sim_x zy∼x​z iff f(x,y)=f(x,z)f(x,y)=f(x,z)f(x,y)=f(x,z). Let RxiR^i_xRxi​ for 1≤i≤mx1\leq i\leq m_x1≤i≤mx​ be the equivalence classes of [n]/∼x[n]/\sim_x[n]/∼x​ and cxic^i_xcxi​ be their respective cardinals. Then the partition structure of RxR_xRx​ affects mxm_xmx​ other rows, saying that if a∈Rxia\in R^i_xa∈Rxi​ then the g(x,a)g(x,a)g(x,a)-th row has at least cxic^i_xcxi​ elements (partitions). In particular, if RxR_xRx​ has exactly two elements, then it has Rx1,Rx2R^1_x, R^2_xRx1​,Rx2​ with cardinals n/2+k,n/2−kn/2+k, n/2-kn/2+k,n/2−k, and hence there are two other rows with at least n/2+kn/2+kn/2+k and n/2−kn/2-kn/2−k elements respectively (so having at least 222 elements per row is not the end of the story when accounting for the sum).

Also of potential interest is that RxiR^i_xRxi​ forces g(x,⋅)g(x,\cdot)g(x,⋅) to have at least cxic^i_xcxi​ different elements in its range (which may be quite more than n1/2n^{1/2}n1/2).

At the moment I don't see how to integrate the global conditions arising from the partitions of all rows in order to find the minimal sum (because a "descendant" row can have its "parent" as "descendant"). Do you have any ideas? :star_struck:

But we can show that F(n)F(n)F(n) cannot be n2/2n^2/2n2/2: the following optimal model for size n=6n=6n=6 shows F(6)=15<18=36/2F(6) = 15 < 18 = 36/2F(6)=15<18=36/2.

Nevertheless, this combinatorial problem doesn't fully capture all the restrictions of your original 677-inspired problem, for which I still believe F(n)F(n)F(n) may be bounded from below by n2/2n^2/2n2/2, and for which a check of all isoclasses for sizes 4−64-64−6 suggest more: that even for each fixed row, the cardinal of the range cannot be smaller than n/2n/2n/2 (may be a small-numbers mirage). Here the fact that f,gf,gf,g are related through the product is relevant, and not fully captured by condition 2) in my problem above (e.g. we have g(y∗x,f(x,y))=yg(y*x,f(x,y)) = yg(y∗x,f(x,y))=y).

Some assorted observations:

  • Notice that the argument translated by @Terence Tao above shows that there is a unique yyy such that LyL_yLy​ fixes xxx. In a linear model 1−b1 - b1−b is invertible iff every LyL_yLy​ fixes some xxx, in which case there is a bijection between fixers and fixpoints. (Notice that in Type 1 models 1−b=a1 - b = a1−b=a, so we know it's invertible. Not sure about Type 2 -- is 1−b1 - b1−b always invertible if nonzero?) We might try to find a counterexample where all of the LxL_xLx​ have no fixpoints, or show that it can't exist.
  • In a linear model Lk=1L_k = 1Lk​=1 implies k=0,(a,b)=(4,1)k = 0, (a, b) = (4, 1)k=0,(a,b)=(4,1) and that the characteristic is 7. And in fact these models all work.
  • In all cyclic linear models other than the characteristic 7 ones above (and the order 9 and 16 models), all of the LxL_xLx​'s appear to be conjugate as permutations, and always have orbits of equal size other than the unique fixpoint - not sure why this is. But it is not true in the order 25 model, and this is also a model where some LxL_xLx​ is neither the identity nor has <= 1 fixpoints: L7kL_{7k}L7k​ fixes 7k7k7k through 7k+67k + 67k+6.

I also tried to manually prove that there is no model (or countermodel) of various orders in order to gain some insight, here are a couple small results:

  • LaL_aLa​ cannot have a 2-cycle containing aaa.
  • If ab=bab = bab=b and ba=aba = aba=a then a=ba = ba=b, i.e. there are no mutual fixpoints.

It wasn't too hard to show that there's no model of order 2 or 3, but even at order 4 the cases start to become unmanageable, there seems to be no clear pattern. So then I wrote a finite model builder in Ruby specialized to finding a counterexample for 677 => 255, it's much slower than Vampire (got up to size 7 in runs, and non-exhaustively -- it assumes the model consists only of left powers of the counterexample) but also easier to change and can give intermediate output. Code is here along with some general code about linear models and 1518 and 677 in particular.

Note that all models found so far, including the extension models, are cancellative. If a magma is linear then

L0(x)=a0+bx=bxL_0(x) = a0 + bx = bxL0​(x)=a0+bx=bx

R0(x)=ax+b0=axR_0(x) = ax + b0 = axR0​(x)=ax+b0=ax

So if it's cancellative and finite, aaa and bbb must be invertible, and

L0−1(x)=b−1xL_0^{-1}(x) = b^{-1}xL0−1​(x)=b−1x

R0−1(x)=a−1xR_0^{-1}(x) = a^{-1}xR0−1​(x)=a−1x

so we can recover the addition operation via

x+y=(R0−1x)⋄(L0−1y)x + y = (R_0^{-1}x)\diamond (L_0^{-1}y)x+y=(R0−1​x)⋄(L0−1​y)

So more generally, if a magma (M,⋄)(M, \diamond)(M,⋄) is cancellative and has an idempotent zzz then this construction will work and give an auxiliary cancellative magma (A(M),+)(A(M), +)(A(M),+) with the same carrier in which we have x⋄y=f(x)+g(y)x \diamond y = f(x) + g(y)x⋄y=f(x)+g(y) for some invertible functions f,gf, gf,g that fix zzz. Then zzz is a 2-sided identity for +++, but +++ need not be either associative or commutative, nor do fff and ggg need to be homomorphisms (distributive). This is similar to the twisting construction.

I tested this on the extension models found by @Matthew Bolan here. All of them have idempotents (and sometimes every element is an idempotent). Some of them don't give a commutative auxiliary magma for any choice of idempotent, some give a commutative one for only a single choice of idempotent. But only three give an associative auxiliary magma: the first (index 0) magma (of order 25), and two magmas of order 121 (at indices 98 and 240). All three are idempotent, and any element works as the 0.

Note that a finite cancellative unital magma will have both left and right inverses because LxL_xLx​ and RxR_xRx​ are surjective. If the magma is commutative then they are equal by cancellativity, and if the magma is associative these inverses will be equal by the usual argument. So in fact all of the commutative auxiliary magmas have inverses including the three associative ones, so they are in fact abelian groups. And according to my calculations the functions are also homomorphisms, so these could be linear. I am not sure how to determine whether they admit a ring structure that makes the homomorphisms into left-multiplication operations.

All code is here, along with the three pseudolinear magmas and their associated abelian groups (in magma_tables.rb) for anyone who wants to see or check for themselves.

@Ibrahim Tencer I think it is good to try to see if by any chance all of the linear and cohomological models share some properties that can be abstracted and perhaps proven for general models.

  • Terry's argument tells us that y⋄x=xy\diamond x=xy⋄x=x implies y=(x⋄x)⋄xy = (x\diamond x)\diamond xy=(x⋄x)⋄x actually, so indeed we have uniqueness. It's interesting that the map x↦(x⋄x)⋄xx\mapsto (x\diamond x)\diamond xx↦(x⋄x)⋄x from fixpoint to fixer is bijective in all linear models (except one). Is it also the case in cohomological extensions? The one exception that you mentioned is the unique characteristic 777 model with a=4,b=1a=4,b=1a=4,b=1 (the constant terms is irrelevant so there is a unique such model up to isomorphism); otherwise 1−b1-b1−b is always invertible.

  • An explanation for why LxL_xLx​ of linear models are conjugate by a bijection f(y)=y+kf(y)=y+kf(y)=y+k: we have f(Lx(f−1(y)))=ax+b(y−k)+k=a(x+a−1(1−b)k)+by=Lx+a−1(1−b)f(L_x(f^{-1}(y)))=ax+b(y-k)+k = a(x + a^{-1}(1-b)k) + by = L_{x+a^{-1}(1-b)}f(Lx​(f−1(y)))=ax+b(y−k)+k=a(x+a−1(1−b)k)+by=Lx+a−1(1−b)​, which can typically reach all LxL_xLx​, unless 1−b1-b1−b is non-invertible. I didn't track down why there are two other exceptions of order 9 and 16, it might be interesting. It's really interesting that the cohomological models are richer in this respect. It might be possible to get some intuition about the "flow of information" by looking at these models.

  • One thing to investigate by hand/script maybe would be whether we can make a model of size nnn with some undetermined entries (that will be later set to values larger than nnn) that obeys the magma rule whenever all the relevant entries are determined, then slowly add more elements (increase nnn) as needed, and try to make multiplication tables that are as full as possible. One has to impose left-cancellability properly to avoid creating permanent obstructions that will never disappear as we increase nnn.

The point is that we don't actually have to embed the group inside the ring to define a linear model: you only need the ring to act on the abelian group to define x⋄y=a⋅x+b⋅yx\diamond y = a\cdot x + b\cdot yx⋄y=a⋅x+b⋅y (with the dot denoting the action of ring elements a,ba,ba,b on group elements x,yx,yx,y) and compute expressions such as (x⋄y)⋄z=a⋅(a⋅x+b⋅y)+b⋅z=a2⋅x+(ab)⋅y+b⋅z(x\diamond y)\diamond z = a\cdot (a\cdot x+b\cdot y)+b\cdot z=a^2\cdot x+(ab)\cdot y+b\cdot z(x⋄y)⋄z=a⋅(a⋅x+b⋅y)+b⋅z=a2⋅x+(ab)⋅y+b⋅z with all the usual distributive rules because by definition of an action we have a⋅(b⋅y)=(ab)⋅ya\cdot(b\cdot y) = (ab)\cdot ya⋅(b⋅y)=(ab)⋅y.

So if you have a magma on GGG with an idempotent 000 such that L0L_0L0​ and R0R_0R0​ are invertible, and if x+y=R0−1(x)⋄L0−1(x)x+y=R_0^{-1}(x)\diamond L_0^{-1}(x)x+y=R0−1​(x)⋄L0−1​(x) defines an abelian group structure on GGG, and if L0L_0L0​ and R0R_0R0​ are homomorphisms of (G,+)(G,+)(G,+), then the magma is linear in the sense that x⋄y=R0(x)+L0(x)x\diamond y = R_0(x) + L_0(x)x⋄y=R0​(x)+L0​(x) with L0,R0∈End(G)L_0,R_0\in\mathrm{End}(G)L0​,R0​∈End(G). It's a lot of conditions, and unfortunately they are not fulfilled as you found in your investigations of the auxiliary magma.
